newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish Jan-Sept '96 registered trade gap $8.27 bln.
newsitem.headline: Polish Jan-Sept '96 registered trade gap $8.27 bln.

text.p: Poland's registered trade gap in the first nine months of 1996 amounted to $8.27 billion against a $3.98-billion shortfall in the same period of 1995, the Central Statistical Office said (GUS).

GUS figures differ from central bank data, which showed a $5.26 billion merchandise trade gap in the first nine months of last year, because the statistical office uses customs receipts, not bank flows to count trade.
GUS said Poland exported goods worth $18.09 billion in the first nine months of last year, or 8.4 percent more than in the same period of 1995.
It imported goods worth $26.36 billion during the period, or 27.5 percent more than in the corresponding months of 1995.
The European Union (EU) was the destination of 66.6 percent of Polish exports and the orgin of 64.0 percent of imports, with bilateral trade worth $28.9 billion, GUS said.
Polish exports to the EU grew 1.2 percent in the January-September period of last year against the same period of 1995, while imports rose 26.2 percent.
Germany remained Poland's top trading partner, with a 34.6 percent share of exports and 24.9 percent of imports.
